metadata.sermon_title: Laodicea, Part III: The Door Of The Soul
metadata.sermon_start_end: We read at Revelation 3:20, "Behold, I stand at the door and knock: if any man hear my voice, and open the door," as it stands in the King James Version, "I will come in to him, and will sup with him, and he with me." [...] I'll see you when the morning comes. Good night! We shall meet on that healthy shore "where sickness and sorrow and pain and death are felt and feared no more!" Good night! I'll see you where God the Son forever reigns and scatters night away. The Lord knocks. Do you hear him?

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on a very famous verse. While it attempts to ground the text in its immediate context (the 'spewing out' of v. 16), it quickly moves into general tropes about 'opening the heart'. It fails to identify what is unique to this specific Laodicean address that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: Take out the eighteenth and nineteenth verses and we get a kind of resounding collision
The door of the heart, your heart, mine, every single one of you.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus on the specific historical and theological situation of the Laodicean church—their self-sufficiency and 'lukewarmness'—rather than turning the 'door' into a general psychological metaphor.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a brief mention of the 'original language' regarding the word 'spew', but it is dismissed for the sake of politeness. The preacher explicitly avoids the 'harshness' of the Greek, which Dekker would find a failure of the office. The historical context of Laodicea is absent.
quotes: I must not use the word again that I used from the original language and which the King James Version sanitized.
I will not use the word for which 'spew' stands, because I saw some of you draw up stiffly.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: The preacher must not 'sanitize' the Word. Use the original Greek terminology to expose the gravity of the text's judgment.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The sermon is concrete in its references to the zeitgeist (industry, corporate life, the White House, the Olympics). However, the application often veers into sentimentality and anecdotal 'storytelling' rather than a sharp theological application of the Word.
quotes: I was spiritually bankrupt... rising in industry and in the corporate life of America.
talking about the matter of the Olympic foundation... this former Secretary of the Treasury.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift from anecdotal sentimentality (the grandmother's hymn, the dying mother) to a more rigorous ethical and dogmatic application of what it means for a 'lukewarm' person to open the door.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a thematic structure rather than an exegetical one. It moves from the text to various 'doors' (conscience, memory, mind). The 'present' of revelation is somewhat obscured by the heavy use of personal anecdotes.
quotes: Perhaps this sermon really should have been entitled 'The Doors of the Soul'
Let me tell you something for which I thank God daily.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the text to 'expound' the hearer rather than using the hearer's psychology to categorize the text.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The 'misery' is present in the discussion of the 'last knock' and being 'spiritually bankrupt'. Redemption is found in Christ's knocking. However, the 'misery' is often presented as psychological distress rather than misery 'before God'.
quotes: I will spew thee out of my mouth. Kaput, the end, it's over, goodbye.
He will bless your life! He will pick you up, set you on a solid rock!
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect by connecting it to the specific sin of Laodicea (spiritual pride) rather than general 'spotted and confused' living.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point in the sermon. The preacher explicitly addresses the 'last knock' and the possibility of being lost, both temporally and eternally. He takes the hearer's responsibility seriously.
quotes: There does come a last knock... Nothing is endless.
They're saved, son, and I will see them again. But if you finish as you are now, I'll never see you.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Ensure the 'two ways' are rooted in the specific call of the text to 'repent' (v. 19) rather than just a general decision for salvation.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the one knocking and the one who saves. However, the sermon occasionally borders on 'human-oriented' preaching where Christ becomes a means to a better life (sunshine, food on the table) rather than the telos Himself.
quotes: He'll give you friends, and he'll put food on your table!
Christ is the telos... Christ is his life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Focus on Christ as the 'Amen, the faithful and true witness' (v. 14) to ground His authority, rather than just His utility for a happy life.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 2100 words, the sermon meets Dekker's requirement for 'breadth'. It allows for multiple illustrations and a slow build-up of urgency.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Trade some of the anecdotal breadth for exegetical depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a rhetorically strong appeal that takes the 'two ways' seriously, but it falls short of Dekker's ideal by sanitizing the harshness of the biblical text and relying heavily on sentimental anecdotes. The exegesis is thin, and the application is more psychological than dogmatic.
strengths: Strong emphasis on the 'two ways' and the reality of being lost.
Adequate length that allows for the development of urgency.
Clear attempt to connect the text to contemporary figures and the zeitgeist.
weaknesses: Sanitization of the biblical text ('spew') to avoid offending the audience.
Over-reliance on anecdotes (the rancher, the dying mother) which distracts from the specific Word.
Lack of specific exegesis regarding the unique context of the Laodicean church.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'speech about the gospel' that uses a Bible passage as a springboard, but it struggles to be a 'sermon' in Dekker's strict sense because it lacks specific exposition and prioritizes psychological sentiment over the 'new, current, proclamatory word' of the specific text.
